message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The family history and presentation of hemarthrosis are suggestive of a bleeding disorder. The normal platelet count and PT suggest a defect in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, which is seen in Hemophilia A. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue, Von Willebrand disease is a bleeding disorder that affects platelet function, and Bernard-Soulier disease is a rare bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the platelet glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex. None of these conditions are as likely as Hemophilia A given the patient's presentation and lab results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The family history, symptoms and physical examination suggest hemophilia A. Marfan syndrome would present with cataracts and aortic root dilation, Von Willebrand disease can cause easy bruising but not joint bleeding, and Bernard-Soulier disease presents with prolonged bleeding time and moderate thrombocytopenia. The coagulation test results are also consistent with hemophilia A, as the partial thromboplastin time is prolonged.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of an 18-month-old boy with swelling in his knee after physical activity, along with a family history of similar problems, suggests a bleeding disorder. The normal platelet count and the prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) indicate a coagulation factor deficiency, which is consistent with Hemophilia A. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting the connective tissue, causing abnormalities in the skeletal, ocular, and cardiovascular systems. Von Willebrand disease is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor. Bernard-Soulier disease is a rare, inherited bleeding disorder characterized by deficient platelet function due to a defect in the glycoprotein Ib/IX/V complex. None of these conditions fit the presentation of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and family history suggest a bleeding disorder. Hemophilia A is a hereditary bleeding disorder caused by deficiency or dysfunction of clotting factor VIII, which is most likely the diagnosis in this case. Von Willebrand disease and Bernard-Soulier disease are also bleeding disorders caused by deficiencies or abnormalities in clotting factors or platelets, but they are less likely given the patient’s presentation. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissue and can cause joint pain and dislocation, but does not commonly present with hemarthrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented suggest hemophilia A, which is a genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to control blood clotting or coagulation, leading to spontaneous bleeding. The family history of similar problems adds to the likelihood of this diagnosis. The normal platelet count and PT/INR results rule out Von Willebrand disease and Bernard-Soulier disease, which are platelet disorders. Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder and not related to coagulation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The family history of similar problems and the ultrasound results suggest hemarthrosis, which is the bleeding into joint spaces, and among the options, only Hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder that affects the clotting factor VIII in the blood. The CBC and coagulation test results, which are within normal range, do not suggest any other diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of hemarthrosis and a family history of similar problems suggest a bleeding disorder. The normal platelet count and coagulation test results rule out Bernard-Soulier disease and von Willebrand disease. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder of the connective tissue and not related to bleeding disorders. Hemophilia A is a genetic disorder that affects clotting factors VIII and is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and family history suggest a bleeding disorder, and the hemarthrosis in the knee confirms it. The normal platelet count rules out Bernard-Soulier disease, and the normal coagulation test results rule out Von Willebrand disease. The prolonged partial thromboplastin time suggests Hemophilia A as the most likely diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and family history of possible bleeding disorder suggest Hemophilia A as the most likely diagnosis. Low platelet count or abnormal platelet function would have been observed in Bernard-Soulier disease and Von Willebrand disease. Marfan syndrome may present with joint pain but not hemarthrosis. The coagulation test results also support Hemophilia A with the prolonged APTT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a hemarthrosis and no history of injury, which suggests a bleeding disorder. The CBC and coagulation tests are normal, except for prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), which is consistent with Hemophilia A. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting the connective tissue, Von Willebrand disease is a bleeding disorder that causes prolonged bleeding time, and Bernard-Soulier disease is a rare disorder that affects platelet function. None of them fit the patient's presentation as well as Hemophilia A.
